properties.ingress:
One of the biggest impacts of this pandemic on my daily life is that I am working from home now. Although I am used to working remotely, a lot of my colleagues are not. Many are struggling with using new software or digital tools they have never used before. Especially staying in touch and keeping our projects and activities running is a challenge. We use video-conference calls and chat programs to exchange information within the team, but it is just not the same experience than meeting a random colleague in the hallway. It also limits the circle of people you are regularly in touch with to the people who are at ease with digital communication - or to your closest teammates. 

Apart from how my work situation has changed, I see the biggest transformation in my social life. I am single and living alone, so not going to work also means that I do not see and meet as many people as I did before. For most of my colleagues, working from home means that they spend more time with their families or flatmates (with all positive and negative effects that result from this). For me, it really means being alone most of the day.

I am not Swedish, but German. When it became apparent that traveling will be more difficult, it also made me feel uncertain when I would actually see my family and friends again. I had a trip home planned, but decided not to travel as I did not want to put others in danger by spreading the virus. Although I am not part of the risk groups, I think it is unreasonable to travel if it is not necessary right now. 

Right now, I am more happy than ever that I have access to the internet and online communication. Apart from the distraction that online streaming services offer, it is such a relief that I can easily ring my grandmother and parents, exchange chat messages and have video calls with friends. I am quite aware of how this situation had been incredibly more difficult for me if we would have experienced this just a few years ago. Being able to check in with my loved ones is so important to me, I cannot imagine what this would be like with digital tools and a good internet connection.

properties.ingress:
Today is the 25th of March 2020, and I have been in self-isolation for 14 days. Only my boyfriend and flatmate have come to the house.

I'm doing this because I have asthma. All the guidance from the World Health Organisation points towards asthma being a significant risk factor for becoming seriously ill due to the coronavirus. I'm only 28 but I am low-key terrified. 

I thought this country would be my home. I saw my future here. Now that is something I question. Watching the whole country debate whether it's worth protecting people like me, older people, people with diabetes, heart conditions, lung disease, cancer, anything really... apparently our lives are far less important than the economy. 

I am sickened. Full of fear. I wonder if I should try and get out, go back to my native country of Ireland, leave my life and my boyfriend behind here. Europeans, in this time, we don't think terrible things should happen to us, that somehow we are not deserving of them because we are so modern, or something like that. Life has changed utterly. Now I understand why people flee.

properties.ingress:
ELEFANTEN P√Ö MINA LUNGOR
Det h√§r √§r min ber√§ttelse om att ha covid-19. Jag har skrivit p√• engelska, hoppas det fungerar √§nd√•.
Allt gott
/Nanda Jansson

Two nights ago, after four days with a growing sense of fatigue, lung pain and fever-like feelings in my body (without having a fever), I woke up at 3.10 in the morning and felt like there was an elephant sitting on my chest. My lungs felt so tight and even though there was nothing physically blocking my lungs, it was taking strength to breathe. I have never felt like this before in my life. I couldn‚Äôt lie in my bed anymore, so I went up and made myself some tea. I could feel panic rising inside me. Would I still be able to breathe in an hour, two hours from now? Is this the time to go to the hospital? I decided to wake my husband and asked him to sit with me. I started talking to him and my body started shaking. I recognized this type of shaking: it‚Äôs what my body does when it‚Äôs overwhelmed with fear. I decided to call the national health service to get some advice. Even in the middle of the night there was a 40-minute waiting queue before someone answered the phone. When a nurse answered the phone, I apologized for burdening the system but I felt that I had a burning question: how do I know when it‚Äôs time to go to the hospital? The woman said that because I was still able to talk, I should stay at home. So that‚Äôs what I did. Me and the elephant on my lungs. 

I decided to call him Dumbo.

The following 18 hours were very challenging for me. Physically because it was seriously more difficult to breathe and my lungs hurt a lot, but also mentally. Because suddenly I was facing my fear of dying. It did not matter that I had read covid-19 statistics and that it is most dangerous for people with underlying health-issues or who are elderly. Because here I was, having difficulty doing one of the most basic things a human being does: breathing freely. I cannot imagine anyone experiencing this and not being affected by it mentally.

So, what did I do?

I decided to make a meditation out of it. What do I mean by that? Well, I decided to acknowledge and fully be present with everything that I was experiencing. And by that, I mean: EVERYTHING. So, I said to myself: what is it I am feeling? FEAR. Well, hello fear, there you are. I asked myself again: what is it I am feeling more? PAIN. Hello pain, there you are in my lungs. I asked myself again: what is it I am feeling? SHAME. Hello shame, there you are. I felt shame for calling the health service and I felt shame for waking my husband from his sleep in the middle of the night. I asked myself again: what is it I am feeling more? ALONE. Hello alone-ness, there you are. When experiencing something like this, I suddenly felt incredibly alone. I also felt SADNESS, FRUSTRATION and a huge amount of VULNERABILITY.
On, and on I went like this. Being with Dumbo sitting on my lungs, slowly and carefully examining all of my feelings and not pushing any of them away. Curiously asking myself: what is it I am feeling? And fully allowing whatever my feelings were. I am convinced this is what kept me from going into full-panic-hyperventilation-mode. 

You know what I also felt? GRATEFUL. I feel so incredibly grateful for my life! For the people in my life and all the gifts in it. I‚Äôm so deeply privileged! One particular dear friend (you know who you are) decided to take some of her time, connected with me from her home and sat with me on a deep level. She told me: Nanda, it‚Äôs time to wake up. And when she said that, it totally clicked for me. That is exactly right! What is it that I‚Äôm still doing in my life, when I hold myself back? Because even though I have done so much these past few years especially; moving to Spain, publishing my blog www.livingmytruth.se, becoming an entrepreneur, starting my own holistic counseling-practice‚Ä¶. I am still not showing the world the True Me, many times! I still laugh sometimes when someone says something that in fact makes me angry. I still say things to people sometimes because I think that‚Äôs what they want to hear so they don‚Äôt get upset with me instead of speaking my truth. What the h*** am I doing when I do that? I almost feel fake: look at the title of my blog for crying out loud?! Living My Truth. But am I doing that, really? If I answer honestly: no, I still am not. Not totally. I still haven‚Äôt gone All-In when it comes to living my life. I feel I have huge potential and I‚Äôm still holding so much of it back. So that‚Äôs what I will focus on even more in the upcoming times (and probably the rest of my life). How can I live my life in a way that feels true to me? Where I dare to be vulnerable, really show up and step into the arena?

I can‚Äôt find words to describe how grateful I am for these past days, however frightening some parts of it were. Having faced all of these deep feelings inside me and really staying with them instead of pushing them away has shaken me up and I really needed that.
As I‚Äôm writing this today, Dumbo has replaced itself for Pluto. And it‚Äôs such a relief! It‚Äôs much easier to handle this feeling in my body and mentally not spinning as much. I hope that by tomorrow, Pluto is gone as well. Perhaps replaced by Jerry (you know, from Tom) but hopefully soon my lungs will feel Disney-character-free and I can focus on what‚Äôs next. What that will be exactly? I have no idea. But I‚Äôm still here and I will keep on exploring. Thank you.

With love to you who is reading this, I wish you all the best in these challenging times

properties.ingress:
Please excuse me for writing in English. 

I'm probably one of those who should complain the least and be grateful for my situation. I've been studying in KTH, Stockholm for almost two years, and today I'm at the end phase of my study where I'm writing my thesis (examensarbete) in a Swedish major truck company. I started it with a huge motivation for having a beautiful closure to my journey in KTH. 

The motivation became even bigger when I got a job offer from a Gothenburg-based company early in February when everything was normal in Sweden. I'm going to start working in August and very much looking forward to moving to Gothenburg. Learning that I will be in a better financial situation by summer, I had a lot of things in my mind, one of those was, of course, visiting my home country, Indonesia, to have what could possibly have been the best vacation in my life. Side note, during my two-year stay in Sweden, I haven't visited my family back home at all. The reason behind that has been that I don't want to lose momentum throughout my studies. That is why this much-needed vacation would've been wonderful.

Then the COVID-19 situation worsened. I will start with the one I am grateful for the most. I'm probably the luckiest person in my class to have been offered a job and signed the contract that early when the situation was all normal. As per the time of writing, we all know that the job market is plummeting along with the global economy.

Meanwhile, the company where I'm doing my examensarbete is closing down its manufacturing plants, and encouraging the employees, including me, to work from home. It definitely affects me in many ways. 

1). Productivity
I'm used to sit in an open-space office where I can chat with people at the pantry whenever I want. Although I mostly work in front of the computer, I really like to make connections with people. I didn't know that I'm that deprived of human connections until the second week of working from home. I've always thought that I'm more towards the introverted extreme of the spectrum. Well, now I understand that I'm not introverted to that extent. That somehow reduces my productivity so much because at home I would usually make phone calls with friends or just start a chat with them just because I'm so much in need of emotional stimulants. Although, I have basically the same access to my office computer, the productivity level couldn't be lower than this.

2). Well-being
I have a history of depression in the past. In short, I overcame that when I moved to Sweden. One of the reasons was that Sweden was (and still is) a new place for me with a completely different culture, cuisine, and etiquette. That sort of helped me distract myself from depressing thoughts. Now, practically having no one outside of their homes, I can't even see people. I'm not stupid enough to just go to T-Centralen to see people.

3). News from home
This is the worst part of the pandemic. At the time of writing, one could check the statistics and tell that Indonesia is among the countries with the highest death rate. What worries me is not the lack of our healthcare quality. That is a problem, of course, but being a third-world country, it is somewhat expected of them. To make things worse, the government is not transparent in disclosing its testing capacity, the distribution of the spread, and not to mention the inaccuracy of the statistics. There was a statistic on April 4th that showed a fewer number of cumulative deaths in Jakarta than that from April 3rd.  There was a joke on Twitter that goes, "It's not even either Good Friday or Easter, yet there's already a resurrection".

I really hope that my family and relatives are safe despite the government's apparent incompetence.

Min vardag har sannerligen forandrats de senaste veckorna. Jag bor i England, strax soder om London, och idag ar det Dag 14 av var "Lockdown". Foretaget jag jobbar for har stangt (forhoppningsvis temporart), mina dottrars skola ar stangd (de blir emailade arbetsuppgifter) och min man jobbar hemifran. Mina dottrar ar 15 och 17 ar och de mar under omstandigheterna mycket battre an jag hade trott. Kanske for att de inte har nagon FOMO (fear of missing out) eftersom alla deras vanner ar i samma situation. Vi far fortfarande ga ut och motionera (en gang om dagen) och ga ut och handla mat. Faktiskt kanner vi alla att det hittills har varit ganska skont med en paus I vara vanligtvis oerhort hektiska liv. Det har varit jatteskont att kunna pula lite i hemmet och i tradgarden (det fina varvadret har naturligtvis hjalpt till att halla humoret uppe). Jag forsoker gora nagot av nytta varje dag, men har aven blivit av med skuldkanslorna jag brukade ha om jag inte hade gjort 1000 saker pa en ledig dag. 
Jag ar dock orolig for min mor och bror i Sverige. Jag hoppas verkligen att de bada haller sig friska. Det skall bli intressant att se om nagra manader hur situationen i Sverige ar i forhallande till resten av varlden som tagit mycket strangare steg i kampen mot coronan.

properties.ingress: My everyday life has been greatly affected. There is so much I want to do that I do not have the opportunity to do. But the biggest change has happened for my grandmother, which has affected my everyday life very much. One month before corona came to Sweden, my grandfather died of a stroke. As a result, Grandma lost the love of her life and then became isolated due to corona. Grandma's loneliness has affected me enormously as a result. It has been my and my family's responsibility to make sure that she can process her grief in a good way, that she eats properly and that she has all the things to live on as best she can. To meet my grandmother and be able to process the grief with her, I have had to isolate myself and really distance myself from other people so that I can be with her. I try not to meet more than my family for 10 days before I meet grandma. This has resulted in me spending very little time with other people outside the family just so I can be with Grandma for most days of a week. As a result, corona has mostly affected me in such a way that I have had to choose between meeting my friends or not meeting my grandmother in two weeks. Because I'm so close to my Grandma, I have not been much with my friends during the time Corona has been around.

properties.ingress:
Corona has been part of my life for almost exactly a year now. ‚Ä®
While I was still living in Berlin, I quickly noticed the effects: for several weeks all shops were suddenly closed except for supermarkets. No restaurants, no bars, museums, theaters, and certainly no concerts or clubs. There was absolutely nothing happening in public life. A complete shut down.
I still remember the first few days when I noticed: This is serious. When I saw the first person with a mask in a drugstore (who was just discussing with a cashier how many packs of toilet paper she was entitled to buying), I thought: Crazy. At that time I still considered wearing a mask to be exaggerated and paranoid, a few weeks later it was mandatory to wear a mask in every store and on the bus and subway too. And it still is. And it will probably stay that way for quite a long time, even if the pandemic will be over eventually.
I remember it was an exciting time when the first thing in the morning I did was to update the live ticker, check the infection numbers for my area, to see what things shut down next. But I was never very afraid of getting infected with Corona or of being isolated. I have to admit, I actually enjoyed the regular life being suspended for a while. I liked the state of emergency, the weird sense of being united through this crisis. I spent the first few weeks of the lockdown alone in my apartment. I rode my bike a lot, facetimed a lot with my friends, went grocery shopping and cooked, and did spring cleaning. Everything you could do at home. During the first lockdown in March 2020, I neither studied nor worked, which is why I was able to do whatever I wanted with my time. After a while I decided to move with a friend of mine (Lars) into his boyfriends (Emil) flat share for some weeks, as Emil was locked down with his parents in Vienna and his apartment was vacant. So after almost a month of being alone I was in a shared apartment in Neuk√∂lln, sort of like a small move during the lockdown. I brought a lot of art materials and movies, but most of the time I watched Netflix and played Sims and baked bread with Lars. It was good not to be alone, although in lockdown I noticed how well I can spend my time on my own. But it wasn't like that at all for many of my friends. One of my closest friends was staying together with her boyfriend in his flat share with 5 other people. She couldn ÃÅt cope witht the lockdown at all, had to start therapy and was having frequent panic attacks.
